Name: C Pop Standard
Description: Classic four-chord loop in key of C

Name: C Folk Turn
Description: Loop with motion back to G

Name: G Minor Emotion
Description: In G key, but Em led

Name: C Circle Progression
Chords: C | F | Bdim | Em | Am | Dm | G | C

Name: G Circle Progression
Chords: G | C | F#dim | Bm | Em | Am | D | G

Name: D Circle Progression
Chords: D | G | C#dim | F#m | Bm | Em | A | D

Name: A Circle Progression
Chords: A | D | G#dim | C#m | F#m | Bm | E | A

Name: E Circle Progression
Chords: E | A | D#dim | G#m | C#m | F#m | B | E

Name: F Circle Progression
Chords: F | Bb | Edim | Am | Dm | Gm | C | F

Name: Bb Circle Progression
Chords: Bb | Eb | Adim | Dm | Gm | Cm | F | Bb

Name: Extended Cadence
Description: Embellished cadence cycle common in Chopin’s endings.

Name: Deceptive Cadence
Description: Dominant moves deceptively to vi (relative minor).

Name: Chromatic Cadence
Description: Use of borrowed mediant chord for tension.

Name: Borrowed Minor
Description: Use of iv from parallel minor.

Name: Augmented Sixth Cadence
Description: German augmented sixth chord resolving to dominant.

Name: Minor Lament
Description: Descending bass in a minor key.

Name: Picardy Third
Description: Minor work ending with raised third.

Name: Dreamy Nights
Description: Classic ii–V–I with a lo-fi touch, jazzy and smooth.

Name: Midnight Study
Description: Jazzy cycle through major 7ths with tension–release.

Name: Rainy Mood
Description: ii–V–I with a borrowed dominant for color.

Name: Chillhop Flow
Description: Relaxed turnaround, common in lo-fi beats.

Name: Sunset Haze
Description: Smooth ii–V–I ending on lush maj9.

Name: Study Session
Description: ii–V–I–IV in D, bright but chilled.

Name: Vinyl Dust
Description: Soulful, common in sampled jazz chords.

Name: Nostalgia Loop
Description: Simple but enhanced with G13 at the end.

Name: Cozy Room
Description: Expansive IV and V with soft cadence.

Name: Candlelight
Description: Classic jazz vibe with lo-fi warmth.

Name: Standard 12-Bar Blues (C)
Description: The foundation of blues music, classic 12-bar form with I7, IV7, V7.

Name: Quick Change Blues (C)
Description: Same as standard 12-bar but with an early IV chord at bar 2.

Name: Slow Blues (A)
Description: Minor chromatic passing chords for emotional, slow blues feel.

Name: Jazz Blues (Bb)
Description: Adds ii–V substitutions for a more complex jazz sound.

Name: Minor Blues (Cm)
Description: Classic minor blues with dim7 passing chord.

Name: Stormy Monday Blues (G)
Description: T-Bone Walker’s jazz-inspired slow blues progression.

Name: Chicago Shuffle Blues (E)
Description: Standard Chicago electric blues shuffle, very common in rock.

Name: Texas Blues (D)
Description: Texas blues style, strong I7 emphasis.

Name: Rock Blues (A)
Description: Power chord-based blues for rock/blues crossover.

Name: Turnaround Blues (C)
Description: Standard blues turnaround progression, resolves strongly back to I.

Name: Classic 12-Bar Blues in G
Description: Standard 12-bar blues form, key of G.

Name: Quick Change Blues in A
Description: Blues with an early chord change, key of A.

Name: Slow Blues in C
Description: Slow drag-style blues, includes F#dim7 passing chord.

Name: Chicago Blues in D
Description: Chicago-style shuffle progression, key of D.

Name: Minor Blues in Am
Description: A minor blues progression often used in jazz and funk.

Name: Jazz Blues in Bb
Description: Jazz-influenced blues with II-V cadences and substitutions.

Name: Texas Blues in E
Description: Texas shuffle-style blues progression, key of E.

Name: West Coast Blues in F
Description: Jazzy, jump blues progression with diminished passing chord.

Name: Gospel Blues in C
Description: Gospel-flavored blues with strong IV and V pull.

Name: Standard 12-Bar Blues in C
Description: The classic 12-bar shuffle in C, foundational for all blues playing.

Name: Quick Change Blues in G
Description: Quick change (I–IV in bar 2), adding harmonic motion.

Name: Jazz-Blues in F
Description: Enriched with ii–V substitutions and passing chords.

Name: Minor Blues in Am
Description: Standard 12-bar minor blues, moody and darker.

Name: Texas Blues in E
Description: Driving shuffle with a classic Texas roadhouse feel.

Name: Chicago Blues in D
Description: Incorporates chromatic diminished movement and turnarounds.

Name: Uptown Blues in Bb
Description: A brighter blues with diminished and secondary dominants.

Name: Country Blues in A
Description: Typical country shuffle, often used with steel guitar.

Name: Slow Blues in F#
Description: A heavy, soulful slow blues form.

Name: Standard 12-Bar Blues in C
Description: Classic 12-bar blues progression in C major, staple for countless blues songs.

Name: Quick Change Blues in G
Description: Uses the quick change (IV in bar 2) for variety, key of G.

Name: Minor Blues in Dm
Description: Minor 12-bar blues in D minor, often used in jazz-blues.

Name: Jazz Blues in F
Description: Adds ii–V turnarounds and passing chords, classic jazz-style blues.

Name: Slow Blues in A
Description: Slow expressive A blues, common in guitar-driven ballads.

Name: Funky Blues in E
Description: Upbeat, funky blues in E, with dominant substitutions for groove.

Name: Turnaround Blues in Bb
Description: Strong turnaround emphasis, Bb blues with chromatic approach chords.

Name: Gospel-Style Blues in G
Description: Incorporates gospel-inspired chords in G, very soulful.

Name: Delta Blues in D
Description: Simple raw Delta blues feel in D, traditional bottleneck/slide vibe.

Name: Stormy Monday Changes (T-Bone Walker style)
Description: Based on “Stormy Monday”, chromatic & jazzy in G.
